Using the property that the logarithmic \[\log_{b}(x)\] and the exponential function \[b^{x}\] are inverses what is the simplified form of the expression \[\frac{e^{\ln(2x)} + e^{\ln(-2x)}}{2}\]?

\[0\]

\[x\]

\[\frac{1}{2}\]

\[\frac{e^{4x}}{2}\]

\[0\]

Using the property that the logarithmic \[\log_{b}(x)\] and the exponential function \[b^{x}\] are inverses the simplified form of the expression \[\frac{e^{\ln(2x)} + e^{\ln(2x)}}{2}\] is \[\frac{2x+(-2x)}{2}=0\].

Evaluate \[\tanh^{-1}(1/2).\]

Using the definition of the \[\tanh^{-1}x = \frac{1}{2}\ln{\left(\frac{1+x}{1-x}\right)}\], it follows that

\[\tanh^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) = \frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 + \frac{1}{2}}{1 - \frac{1}{2}}\right).\]

easy

What is the definition of \[\tanh^{-1}x\]?

\[\tanh^{-1}x = \frac{1}{2}\ln{\left(\frac{1+x}{1-x}\right)}\]

\[\tanh^{-1}x = \ln{\left(\frac{1+x}{1-x}\right)}\]

\[\tanh^{-1}x = \frac{1}{2}\ln{\left(\frac{1-x}{1+x}\right)}\]

\[\tanh^{-1}x = \ln{\left(\frac{1-x}{1+x}\right)}\]

\[\tanh^{-1}x = \frac{1}{2}\ln{\left(\frac{1+x}{1-x}\right)}\]

The definition of \[\tanh^{-1}x\] is \[\frac{1}{2}\ln{\left(\frac{1+x}{1-x}\right)}\].

medium

What is the value of \[\tanh^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)\] using the definition of \[\tanh^{-1}x\]?

\[\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 - \frac{1}{3}}{1 + \frac{1}{3}}\right)\]

\[\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 + \frac{1}{3}}{1 - \frac{1}{3}}\right)\]

\[\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 + \frac{3}{1}}{1 - \frac{3}{1}}\right)\]

\[\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 - \frac{3}{1}}{1 + \frac{3}{1}}\right)\]

\[\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 + \frac{1}{3}}{1 - \frac{1}{3}}\right)\]

Using the definition of \[\tanh^{-1}x\], the value of \[\tanh^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)\] is \[\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 + \frac{1}{3}}{1 - \frac{1}{3}}\right)\].

difficult

What is the value of \[\tanh^{-1}(\frac{a}{c})\] using the definition of \[\tanh^{-1}x\]?

\[\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 + \frac{a}{c}}{1 - \frac{a}{c}}\right)\]

\[\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 - \frac{a}{c}}{1 + \frac{a}{c}}\right)\]

\[\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 + \frac{c}{a}}{1 - \frac{c}{a}}\right)\]

\[\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 - \frac{c}{a}}{1 + \frac{c}{a}}\right)\]

\[\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 + \frac{a}{c}}{1 - \frac{a}{c}}\right)\]

Using the definition of \[\tanh^{-1}x\], the value of \[\tanh^{-1}\left(\frac{a}{c}\right)\] is \[\frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1 + \frac{a}{c}}{1 - \frac{a}{c}}\right)\].

Evaluating the final result using a calculating utility, we get

\[\tanh^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) = \frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{3}{2} \div \frac{1}{2}\right) = \frac{1}{2}\ln\left(3\right) \approx 0.5493.\]

easy

What operation is used to evaluate \[\frac{3}{2} \div \frac{1}{2}\]?

Addition

Subtraction

Multiplication

Division

Division

The operation used to evaluate \[\frac{3}{2} \div \frac{1}{2}\] is division.

medium

What is the result of \[\frac{4}{3} \div \frac{2}{3}\]?

1

2

3

4

2

The result of \[\frac{4}{3} \div \frac{2}{3}\] is 2.

difficult

What is the result of \[\frac{a}{b} \div \frac{c}{d}\]?

\[\frac{a}{c} \times \frac{d}{b}\]

\[\frac{a}{d} \times \frac{c}{b}\]

\[\frac{b}{c} \times \frac{d}{a}\]

\[\frac{b}{d} \times \frac{c}{a}\]

\[\frac{a}{c} \times \frac{d}{b}\]

The result of \[\frac{a}{b} \div \frac{c}{d}\] is \[\frac{a}{c} \times \frac{d}{b}\].

Estimate the slope of the tangent line (rate of change) to \(f(x) = x^2\) at \(x = 1\) by finding the slope of the secant line through \((1,1)\) and the point \(\left(\frac{5}{4}, \frac{25}{16}\right)\) on the graph of \(f(x) = x^2\).

Using the given formula to find the slope of the secant lines through \[(a,f(a))=(1,1)\] and the point \[(\frac{5}{4},\frac{25}{16})\], we get:

\[m_{\text{sec}} = \frac{\frac{25}{16}-1}{\frac{5}{4}-1} = \frac{9}{4}=2.25\]

easy

What is the formula for finding the slope of a line through points \[(a,f(a))\] and \[(b,f(b))\]?

\[m_{\text{sec}} = \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\]

\[m_{\text{sec}} = \frac{f(a)-f(b)}{a-b}\]

\[m_{\text{sec}} = \frac{f(b)+f(a)}{b+a}\]

\[m_{\text{sec}} = \frac{f(a)+f(b)}{a+b}\]

\[m_{\text{sec}} = \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\]

The formula for finding the slope of a line is \[m_{\text{sec}} = \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\].

medium

What is the slope of the secant line through the points \[(a,f(a))=(2,4)\] and \[(3,9)\] on the graph of \[f(x) = x^2\]?

5

6

7

8

5

Using the formula \[m_{\text{sec}} = \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\], we get \[m_{\text{sec}} = \frac{9-4}{3-2} = 5\].

difficult

What is the slope of the secant line through the points \[(a,f(a))=(p,p^2)\] and \[(q,q^2)\] on the graph of \[f(x) = x^2\]?

\[q+p\]

\[q-p\]

\[2q\]

\[2p\]

\[q+p\]

Using the formula \[m_{\text{sec}} = \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}\], we get \[m_{\text{sec}} = \frac{q^2-p^2}{q-p} =\frac{(q+p)(q-p)}{q-p}= q+p\].

The closer the point \[x\] is to \[a\], the better the estimate it gives for the slope of the tangent (rate of change) of \[f(x)\] at \[a\]. As the point \[\frac{5}{4}\] is very close to 1, the corresponding value of the slope of sectant 2.25 provides a good estimate for the slope of the tangent to the function \[f(x)=x^2\] at \[x=1\].

easy

What does the slope of the tangent line at a point on a function graph represent?

The rate of change of the function at that point

The maximum value of the function

The minimum value of the function

The average value of the function

The rate of change of the function at that point

The slope of the tangent line at a point on a function graph represents the rate of change of the function at that point.

medium

Why does the slope of the secant line provide a good estimate for the slope of the tangent line when the points are close together?

Because the secant line intersects the function at two points

Because the secant line is parallel to the tangent line

Because the secant line approximates the tangent line when the points are close together

Because the secant line is perpendicular to the tangent line

Because the secant line approximates the tangent line when the points are close together

The secant line approximates the tangent line when the points are close together, so the slope of the secant line provides a good estimate for the slope of the tangent line.

difficult

The slope of the sectant passing through \[(2,4)\] and which of the following points (x-coordinate) provides a better estimate for the slope of the tangent line to \[f(x) = \frac{x^3}{2}\] at \[x=2\]?

\[3\]

\[\frac{5}{2}\]

\[\frac{9}{4}\]

All of the above provides the same estimate.

\[\frac{9}{4}\]

The point \[\frac{9}{4}\] is closer to \[2\] than \[\frac{5}{2}\] and \[3\], so it provides a better estimate for the slope of the tangent line to \[f(x) = \frac{x^3}{2}\] at \[x = 2\].
learning_objective: The Tangent Problem and Differential Calculus

text:
An object moves along a coordinate axis so that its position at time \[t\] is given by \[s(t) = t^3\]. Estimate its instantaneous velocity at time \[t = 2\] by computing its average velocity over the time interval \[[2, 2.001]\].

Substitute the data into the formula for the definition of average velocity and simplify.

\[
\ v_{ave} = \frac{s(2) - s(2.001)}{2.001 - 2} = \dfrac{2.001^3 - 2^3}{0.001} = 12.006001
\]

Therefore, the instantaneous velocity is approximately \[12.006001\].

easy

The formula \[v_{ave} = \dfrac{s(t_2) + s(t_1)}{t_2 + t_1}\] gives the average velocity over the time interval \[[t_1,t_2]\] where \[s(t)\] is the position function.

True

False

False

The formula for average velocity over the time interval \[[t_1,t_2]\] is given by,
\[v_{ave} = \dfrac{s(t_2) - s(t_1)}{t_2 - t_1}\], where \[s(t)\] is the position function.

medium

If an object moves along a coordinate axis so that its position at time \[t\] is given by \[s(t) = t^2\], what is the displacement at \[t = 4\]?

\[13\]

\[16\]

\[2\]

\[34\]

\[16\]

Substituting \[t = 4\] into the displacement function gives \[s(4) = 4^2 = 16\]

difficult

If an object moves along a coordinate axis so that its position at time \[t\] is given by \[s(t) = t^n\], what is the average velocity over the time interval \[[a, a + h]\]?

\[\dfrac{(a + h)^n - a^n}{h}\]

\[\dfrac{(a + h)^n + a^n}{h}\]

\[\dfrac{(a - h)^n - a^n}{h}\]

\[\dfrac{(a - h)^n + a^n}{h}\]

\[\dfrac{(a + h)^n - a^n}{h}\]

Substitute the data into the formula for the definition of average velocity and simplify:
\[v_{ave} = \dfrac{s(a + h) - s(a)}{a + h - a} = \dfrac{(a + h)^n - a^n}{h}\].
learning_objective: The Tangent Problem and Differential Calculus

text:
Estimate the area between the x-axis and the graph of \(f(x) = x^2 + 1\) over the interval \([0,3]\) by using the three rectangles shown here:

![A graph of the same parabola f(x) = x^2 + 1, but with a different shading strategy over the interval [0,3]. This time, the shaded rectangles are given the height of the taller corner that could intersect with the function. As such, the rectangles go higher than the height of the function.](https://openstax.org/apps/archive/20220801.182716/resources/ecb2cd485e83f43fb0d4c37af052a4b0c11661de)

Area of rectangle = Length\[\cdot\]Width
Area of first rectangle = 1 unit\[\cdot\]2 unit = 2 unit\[^2\]
Area of second rectangle = 1 unit\[\cdot\]5 unit = 5 unit\[^2\]
Area of third rectangle = 1 unit\[\cdot\]10 unit = 10 unit\[^2\]

easy

What is the formula to calculate the area of a rectangle?

Length \[\cdot\] Width

Length + Width

Length - Width

Length / Width

Length \[\cdot\] Width

The area of a rectangle is calculated by multiplying its length by its width.

medium

What is the area of a rectangle with length 5 units and width 6 units?

5 units\[^2\]

6 units\[^2\]

30 units\[^2\]

56 units\[^2\]

30 units\[^2\]

The area of a rectangle is calculated by multiplying its length and width. So, 5 units \[\cdot\] 6 units = 30 units\[^2\].

difficult

What is the area of a rectangle with length \[3m+4n\] units and width \[3m-4n\] units?

\[9m^{2}-4n^{2}\] units\[^2\]

\[3m^{2} -4n^{2}\] units\[^2\]

\[9m^{2}-16n^{2}\] units\[^2\]

\[9m^{2}+16n^{2}\] units\[^2\]

\[9m^{2}-16n^{2}\] units\[^2\]

The area of a rectangle is calculated by multiplying its length and width. So, the area is \[(3m+4n) \cdot (3m-4n) =(3m)^{2} - (4n)^{2} = 9m^{2}-16n^{2}\] units\[^2\].

The areas of the three rectangles are 2 unit², 5 unit², and 10 unit². Sum all these three areas to find the area estimate. 
Area estimate is 2 unit² \[+\]5 unit² \[+\] 10 unit² \[=17\] unit².

easy

What operation is used to combine the areas of multiple shapes to find the total area?

Subtraction

Multiplication

Division

Addition

Addition

Addition is used to combine the areas of multiple shapes to find the total area.

medium

What is the total area of three rectangles with areas 3 unit\[^2\], 4 unit\[^2\], and 5 unit\[^2\]?

12 unit\[^2\]

60 unit\[^2\]

20 unit\[^2\]

2 unit\[^2\]

12 unit\[^2\]

The total area of the rectangles is found by adding the areas of each rectangle. So, 3 unit\[^2\] + 4 unit\[^2\] + 5 unit\[^2\] = 12 unit\[^2\].

difficult

What is the total area of three rectangles with areas \(a^{2}-b^{2}\) unit\[^2\], \(b^{2}\) unit\[^2\], and \(c^{2}\) unit\[^2\]?

\(a^{2}+ b^{2} + c^{2}\) unit\[^2\]

\(a^{2}\cdot b^{2} \cdot c^{2}\) unit\[^2\]

\(a^{2} / b^{2} / c^{2}\) unit\[^2\]

\(a^{2}+ c^{2}\) unit\[^2\]

\(a^{2}+ c^{2}\) unit\[^2\]

The total area of the rectangles is found by adding the areas of each rectangle. So, \(a^{2}-b^{2}\) unit\[^2\] + \(b^{2}\) unit\[^2\] + \(c^{2}\) unit\[^2\] = \(a^{2}-b^{2} + b^{2} + c^{2} =a^{2}+ c^{2} \) unit\[^2\].
learning_objective: The Area Problem and Integral Calculus

text:
Estimate \[\lim_{{x \to 1}} \frac{\frac{1}{x} - 1}{x - 1}\] using a table of functional values. Use a graph to confirm your estimate.

We will use a table—in this case, Table —to list the values of the function for the given values of *x*.

| *x* | \[\frac{\frac{1}{x} - 1}{x - 1}\] | | *x* | \[\frac{\frac{1}{x} - 1}{x - 1}\] |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 0.9 | -1.11111111 | | 1.1 | -0.9090909090 |
| 0.99 | -1.01010101 | | 1.01 | -0.99009900990 |
| 0.999 | -1.001001001 | | 1.001 |- 0.999000999000 |
| 0.9999 | -1.00010001 | | 1.0001 | -0.9999 |
| 0.99999 | -1.0000100001 | | 1.00001 | -0.99999 |

easy

What is the purpose of creating a table of functional values when estimating a limit?

To visualize the function

To find the exact value of the limit

To observe the behavior of the function as it approaches the limit

To solve the function

To observe the behavior of the function as it approaches the limit

Creating a table of functional values allows us to observe the behavior of the function as it approaches the limit, which helps in estimating the limit.

medium

What is the functional value of \[\frac{\frac{1}{x} - 1}{x - 1}\] when \[x = 0.5\]?

-2

-1.5

-1

-0.5

-2

Substituting \[x = 0.5\] into the function \[\frac{\frac{1}{x} - 1}{x - 1}\] gives us -2.

difficult

What is the functional value of \[\frac{\frac{1}{a} - 1}{a - 1}\] when \[a = b\]?

\[\frac{\frac{1}{b} - 1}{b - 1}\]

\[\frac{1 - b}{1 - b}\]

\[\frac{1}{b - 1} - 1\]

\[\frac{1 - \frac{1}{b}}{b - 1}\]

\[\frac{\frac{1}{b} - 1}{b - 1}\]

Substituting \[a = b\] into the function \[\frac{\frac{1}{a} - 1}{a - 1}\] gives us \[\frac{\frac{1}{b} - 1}{b - 1}\].

After inspecting this table, we see that the functional 
values less than 1 appear to be increasing
 toward -1 whereas the functional values greater 
 than 1 appear to be decreasing toward -1. 
We conclude that \[\lim_{{x \to 1}} \frac{\frac{1}{x} - 1}{x -1} = -1.\]

We confirm this estimate using the graph of \[f(x) = \frac{\frac{1}{x} - 1}{x - 1}\] shown in Figure.


https://s3.amazonaws.com/assets.tutorpl.us/mathgpt/images/89/59529100-7f23-4d30-b7e7-34d936919714.png

easy

What does it mean when the functional values are increasing or decreasing toward a certain value?

The function is continuous

The function is discontinuous

The function is approaching a limit

The function is diverging

The function is approaching a limit

When the functional values are increasing or decreasing toward a certain value, it means that the function is approaching a limit.

medium

If the functional values of \[\frac{\frac{1}{x} - 2}{x - 2}\] less than 2 are increasing toward -2 and the functional values greater than 2 are decreasing toward -2, what is the limit as \[x \to 2\]?

-1

-2

0

2

-2

If the functional values less than 2 are increasing toward -2 and the functional values greater than 2 are decreasing toward -2, then the limit as \[x \to 2\] is -2.

difficult

If the functional values of \[\frac{\frac{1}{a} - b}{a - b}\] less than b are increasing toward -b and the functional values greater than b are decreasing toward -b, what is the limit as \[a \to b\]?

-a

-b

0

b

-b

If the functional values less than b are increasing toward -b and the functional values greater than b are decreasing toward -b, then the limit as \[a \to b\] is -b.

Use the graph of \(h(x)\) in Figure 2.16 to evaluate \(\lim_{{x \to 2}} h(x)\), if possible.

![A graph of the function h(x), which is a parabola graphed over [-2.5, 5]. There is an open circle where the vertex should be at the point (2,-1).](https://openstax.org/apps/archive/20220801.182716/resources/bbd87d7303058892cae6af5b50642c460516adc8)

Figure 2.16

As the *x*-values approach 2 from either side, the \[h(x)\] values approach -1. Therefore, \[\lim_{{x \to 2}} g(x) = -1.\] Note that we can determine this limit without even knowing the algebraic expression of the function.

easy

What does it mean when we say 'the limit of a function as x approaches a certain value'?

It's the value that the function approaches as x gets infinitely large.

It's the value that the function approaches as x gets infinitely small.

It's the value that the function approaches as x gets closer to a certain value.

It's the maximum value that the function can reach.

It's the value that the function approaches as x gets closer to a certain value.

The limit of a function as x approaches a certain value is the value that the function approaches as x gets closer to that certain value.

medium

Given a graph of a function f(x) with an open circle at the point (3,4), what would be the limit of f(x) as x approaches 3?

The limit does not exist.

The limit is 3.

The limit is 4.

The limit is undefined.

The limit is 4.

The limit of a function at a certain point is the value that the function approaches as x gets closer to that point. Even if there is an open circle (indicating that the function is not defined at that point), the limit can still exist if the function approaches a specific value.

difficult

Given a graph of a function f(x) with an open circle at the point (a,b), what would be the limit of f(x) as x approaches a?

\[\lim_{{x \to a}} f(x) = a\]

\[\lim_{{x \to a}} f(x) = b\]

\[\lim_{{x \to a}} f(x)\] does not exist

\[\lim_{{x \to a}} f(x)\] is undefined

\[\lim_{{x \to a}} f(x) = b\]

The limit of a function at a certain point is the value that the function approaches as x gets closer to that point. Even if there is an open circle (indicating that the function is not defined at that point), the limit can still exist if the function approaches a specific value.

Use a table of functional values to evaluate \[\lim_{{x \to 2}} \frac{{|x^2 - 4|}}{{x - 2}}\], if possible.



We will approach the \[x\] value from both the side and find the function values. That will help us to evaluate the \[\lim_{{x \to 2}} \frac{{|x^2 - 4|}}{{x - 2}}\].
Let \[f(x)=\frac{{|x^2 - 4|}}{{x - 2}}\]
| \[x\] | \[f(x)\] | | \[x\] | \[f(x)\] |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| \[1.99 \]| \[-3.99\] | | \[2.01\] | \[4.01\] |
|\[ 1.999\] | \[-3.999\]| | \[2.001\] | \[4.001\] |
| \[1.9999 \]|  \[-3.9999\]| | \[2.0001\] | \[4.0001\] |
| \[1.99999\] |\[-3.99999\]  | | \[2.00001 \]| \[4.00001\] |


We see here, when we approach \[x=2\] from left side, \[f(x)\] approach \[-4\] and when we approach \[x=2\]  from the right side, \[f(x)\] approach \[4\]. Since, left hand side and right hand side limits are not equal hence,
\[\lim_{{x \to 2}} \frac{{|x^2 - 4|}}{{x - 2}}= DNE\]

easy

What does DNE stand for in the context of limits?

Does Not Exist

Does Not Equal

Does Not Evaluate

Does Not Extrapolate

Does Not Exist

In the context of limits, DNE stands for 'Does Not Exist'. This is used when the limit of a function at a certain point does not have a finite value.

medium

What does it mean when the left-hand limit and the right-hand limit of a function at a certain point are not equal?

The function is continuous at that point

The function is discontinuous at that point

The function has a maximum at that point

The function has a minimum at that point

The function is discontinuous at that point

If the left-hand limit and the right-hand limit of a function at a certain point are not equal, it means that the function is discontinuous at that point.

difficult

What is the left-hand limit and the right-hand limit of the function \[f(a)=\frac{{|a^2 - b^2|}}{{a - b}}\] repespectively as \[a\] approaches \[b\]?

\[-2b\] and \[2b\]

\[2b\] and \[-2b\]

\[b\] and \[-b\]

\[-b\] and \[b\]

\[-2b\] and \[2b\]

To find the left-hand limit (\[LHL\]) and the right-hand limit (\[RHL\]) of the function \[f(a) = \frac{|a^2 - b^2|}{a - b}\] as \[a\] approaches \[b\], let's create a function value table.

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Approaching } b & f(a) & f(a) = \frac{|a^2 - b^2|}{a - b} \\
\hline
\hline
a < b & \frac{-(a^2 - b^2)}{a - b} = -(a + b) & -(a + b) \\
\hline
a > b & \frac{a^2 - b^2}{a - b} = a + b & a + b \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

Now, let's analyze the limits:

1. Left-hand limit (\[LHL\]):
   \[ \lim_{{a \to b^-}} -(a + b) = -2b \]

2. Right-hand limit (\[RHL\]):
   \[ \lim_{{a \to b^+}} (a + b) = 2b \]

Therefore, the left-hand limit (\[LHL\]) is \[-2b\] and the right-hand limit (\[RHL\]) is \[2b\] as \[a\] approaches \[b\].

Use a table of functional values to estimate the following limits, if possible.

\[\lim_{{x \to 2^-}} \frac{{|x^2 - 4|}}{{x - 2}}\]

We will approach the \[x\] value from left side and find the function values. That will help us to evaluate the \[\lim_{{x \to 2^-}} \frac{{|x^2 - 4|}}{{x - 2}}\].
We know that,  \[f(x)=\frac{{|x^2 - 4|}}{{x - 2}}\]
| \[x\] | \[f(x)\] | 
| --- | --- |
| \[1.99 \]| \[-3.99\] | 
|\[ 1.999\] | \[-3.999\]| 
| \[1.9999 \]|  \[-3.9999\]|
| \[1.99999\] |\[-3.99999\]  |

We see here, when we approach \[x=2\] from left side, \[f(x)\] approach \[-4\].
So,  \[\lim_{{x \to 2^-}} \frac{{|x^2 - 4|}}{{x - 2}}= -4\]

easy

What does the notation \[\lim_{{x \to a^-}} f(x)\] mean?

The limit of the function as \[x\] approaches \[a\] from the right

The limit of the function as \[x\] approaches \[a\] from the left

The limit of the function as \[x\] approaches \[a\] from both sides

The limit of the function as \[x\] approaches infinity

The limit of the function as \[x\] approaches \[a\] from the left

The notation \[\lim_{{x \to a^-}} f(x)\] represents the limit of the function as \[x\] approaches \[a\] from the left.

medium

What is the limit of the function \[f(x)=\frac{{|x^2 - 1|}}{{x - 1}}\] as \[x\] approaches \[1\] from the left?

\[-2\]

\[-1\]

\[1\]

\[2\]

\[-2\]

Let's substitute the values into the function directly to see how \[f(x)\] behaves as \[x\] approaches \[1\] from the left:

\[ f(x) = \frac{|x^2 - 1|}{x - 1} \]

\[
\begin{align*}
x & \quad f(x) \\
0.9 & \quad \frac{|(0.9)^2 - 1|}{0.9 - 1} = \frac{|0.81 - 1|}{-0.1} = \frac{0.19}{-0.1} = -1.9 \\
0.99 & \quad \frac{|(0.99)^2 - 1|}{0.99 - 1} = \frac{|0.9801 - 1|}{-0.01} = \frac{0.0199}{-0.01} = -1.99 \\
0.999 & \quad \frac{|(0.999)^2 - 1|}{0.999 - 1} = \frac{|0.998001 - 1|}{-0.001} = \frac{0.001999}{-0.001} = -1.999 \\
0.9999 & \quad \frac{|(0.9999)^2 - 1|}{0.9999 - 1} = \frac{|0.99960001 - 1|}{-0.0001} = \frac{0.00039999}{-0.0001} = -1.9999 \\
\end{align*}

Let's create a functional value table for the function \[f(x) = \frac{|x^2 - a^2|}{x - a}\] and then evaluate the left-hand limit as \[x\] approaches \[a\] from the left (\[LHL\]):

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\text{Approaching } a & f(x) & f(x) = \frac{|x^2 - a^2|}{x - a} \\
\hline
\hline
x < a & \frac{-(x^2 - a^2)}{x - a} = -(x + a) & -(x + a) \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

Now, let's evaluate the left-hand limit:

\[ \lim_{{x \to a^-}} -(x + a) = -2a \]

Therefore, the limit of the function \[f(x)\] as \[x\] approaches \[a\] from the left is \[-2a\].

\[\lim_{{x \to 5^-}} \frac{1}{(x-5)^2} = 5\]

\[\lim_{{x \to 5^-}} \frac{1}{(x-5)^2} = \infty\]

As \[x\] approaches \[5\] from the left side, the expression \[(x-5)^2\] becomes a very small positive number. Therefore, the function \[f(x) = \frac{1}{(x-5)^2}\] becomes unbounded and approaches positive infinity.

difficult

What is the limit of the function \[f(x) = \frac{1}{(x-a)^n}\] as \[x\] approaches \[a\] from the left side? If \[n>0\].

\[\lim_{{x \to a^-}} \frac{1}{(x-a)^n} = -\infty\] if \[n\] is odd

\[\lim_{{x \to a^-}} \frac{1}{(x-a)^n} = \infty\] if \[n\] is even.

Both A and B

None of the above

Both A and B

As \[x\] approaches \[a\] from the left side, the expression \[(x-a)^n\] becomes a very small negative number if \[n\] is odd, it will become positive number if \[n\] is even. Therefore, the function \[f(x) = \frac{1}{(x-a)^n}\] becomes unbounded and approaches negative infinity when \[n\] is odd and positive infinity when \[n\] is even.

Evaluate each of the following limits. Identify any vertical asymptotes of the function \[f(x) = \frac{1}{(x-2)^3}\].

\[\lim_{{x \to 2^+}} \frac{1}{(x-2)^3}\]

As \[x\] approaches 2 from the right side, the expression \[(x-2)^3\] approaches zero,. But because of the cube exponent, it becomes very small and positive.

So, the limit is of the form \[\frac{1}{\text{small positive number}}\], which tends to positive infinity.

Therefore, \[ \lim_{{x \to 2^+}} \frac{1}{(x-2)^3} = \infty \]

This indicates that as \[x\] approaches 2 from the right side, the function \[f(x) = \frac{1}{(x-2)^3}\] becomes unbounded and approaches positive infinity. The vertical asymptote at \[x = 2\] is evident in this limit evaluation.

easy

What does the \[ \lim_{{x \to 2^+}} f(x)\] denotes?

The value of \[f(x)\] as \[x\] approaches \[2\] from the right.

The limit of \[f(x)\] as \[x\] approaches \[2\] from the right.


The maximum value of \[f(x)\] in the domain of \[x > 2\].

The limit of \[f(x)\] as \[x\] approaches \[2\] from the right.

The limit of \[f(x)\] as \[x\] approaches \[2\] from the right.


The notation \[\lim_{{x \to 2^+}} f(x)\] specifically indicates the limit of the function \[f(x)\] as \[x\] approaches 2 from the right side. It does not represent the actual value of \[f(x)\] at \[x = 2\], but rather the behavior of the function as \[x\] gets arbitrarily close to 2 from the positive side.

Evaluate each of the following limits. Identify any vertical asymptotes of the function \[f(x) = \frac{1}{(x-2)^3}\].

\[\lim_{{x \to 2}} \frac{1}{(x-2)^3}\]

As \[x\] approaches \[2\] from the left side, the expression \[(x-2)^3\] approaches zero, but it does not become zero however, it becomes very small and negative.

\[ \lim_{{x \to 2^-}} \frac{1}{(x-2)^3} \]

As \[x\] approaches \[2\] from the right side, the expression \[(x-2)^3\] approaches zero, but it does not become zero however, it becomes very small and positive.

\[ \lim_{{x \to 2^+}} \frac{1}{(x-2)^3} \]

Since the left-hand limit approaches negative infinity and the right-hand limit approaches positive infinity, the overall limit \[\lim_{{x \to 2}} \frac{1}{(x-2)^3}\] does not exist. The function \[f(x) = \frac{1}{(x-2)^3}\] has a vertical asymptote at \[x = 2\], and the function becomes unbounded as \[x\] approaches \[2\].

Evaluate \[\lim_{{x \to 1}} f(x)\] for \[f(x)\] shown here:



If we approach \[x=1\] from left side, function approaches \[3\]. 
So, \[\lim_{x\rightarrow 1^-} f(x)=3\]

If we approach \[x=1\] from right side, function approaches \[4\]. 
So, \[\lim_{x\rightarrow 1^+} f(x)=4\]

Hence, \[\lim_{x\rightarrow 1^-} f(x) \cancel= \lim_{x\rightarrow 1^+} f(x)\]
Since, left hand limit is not equal to right hand limit then limit at \[x=1\] does not exists.

What does \[\lim_{x\rightarrow a^-} f(x)\] represent?

Use the limit laws to evaluate \[\lim_{{x \to 6}} (2x - 1) \sqrt{x + 4}.\] In each step, indicate the limit law applied.

Apply the product rule for limits 

So, \[\lim_{{x \to 6}} (2x - 1) \sqrt{x + 4} = \lim_{{x \to 6}} (2x - 1) \cdot \lim_{{x \to 6}} \sqrt{x + 4}\].

easy

What is the product rule for limits?

If \[\lim_{{x \to a}} f(x) = L \;\;and\;\; \lim_{{x \to a}} g(x) = M,\; then\; \lim_{{x \to a}} [f(x)g(x)] = LM\]

If \[\lim_{{x \to a}} f(x) = L \;\;and\;\; \lim_{{x \to a}} g(x) = M,\; then\; \lim_{{x \to a}} [f(x)+g(x)] = L+M\]

If \[\lim_{{x \to a}} f(x) = L \;\;and\;\; \lim_{{x \to a}} g(x) = M,\; then\; \lim_{{x \to a}} [f(x)-g(x)] = L-M\]

If \[\lim_{{x \to a}} f(x) = L \;\;and\;\; \lim_{{x \to a}} g(x) = M,\; then\; \lim_{{x \to a}} [f(x)/g(x)] = L/M\]

If \[\lim_{{x \to a}} f(x) = L \;\;and\;\; \lim_{{x \to a}} g(x) = M,\; then\; \lim_{{x \to a}} [f(x)g(x)] = LM\]

The product rule for limits states that the limit of the product of two functions is the product of their limits.

medium

Using the product rule for limits, what is the equivalent form of \[\lim_{{x \to 3}} (x^2 + 2x - 1) \sqrt{x + 5}\]?

\[\lim_{{x \to 3}} (x^2 + 2x - 1) + \lim_{{x \to 3}} \sqrt{x + 5}\]

\[\lim_{{x \to 3}} (x^2 + 2x - 1) - \lim_{{x \to 3}} \sqrt{x + 5}\]

\[\lim_{{x \to 3}} (x^2 + 2x - 1) \cdot \lim_{{x \to 3}} \sqrt{x + 5}\]

\[\lim_{{x \to 3}} (x^2 + 2x - 1) / \lim_{{x \to 3}} \sqrt{x + 5}\]

\[\lim_{{x \to 3}} (x^2 + 2x - 1) \cdot \lim_{{x \to 3}} \sqrt{x + 5}\]

Using the product rule for limits, the expression \[\lim_{{x \to 3}} (x^2 + 2x - 1) \sqrt{x + 5}\] can be rewritten as \[\lim_{{x \to 3}} (x^2 + 2x - 1) \cdot \lim_{{x \to 3}} \sqrt{x + 5}\].

difficult

Using the product rule for limits, what is the equivalent form of \[\lim_{{x \to a}} (ax^2+bx+c) (px^2+qx+r)\]?

\[\lim_{{x \to a}} (ax^2+bx+c) + \lim_{{x \to a}} (px^2+qx+r)\]

\[\lim_{{x \to a}} (ax^2+bx+c) - \lim_{{x \to a}} (px^2+qx+r)\]

\[\lim_{{x \to a}} (ax^2+bx+c) \cdot \lim_{{x \to a}} (px^2+qx+r)\]

\[\lim_{{x \to a}} (ax^2+bx+c) / \lim_{{x \to a}} (px^2+qx+r)\]

\[\lim_{{x \to a}} (ax^2+bx+c) \cdot \lim_{{x \to a}} (px^2+qx+r)\]

Using the product rule for limits, the expression \[\lim_{{x \to a}} (ax^2+bx+c) (px^2+qx+r)\] can be rewritten as \[\lim_{{x \to a}} (ax^2+bx+c) \cdot \lim_{{x \to a}} (px^2+qx+r)\].

Apply the difference law and constant multiple law

So, \[\lim_{{x \to 6}} (2x - 1) \cdot \lim_{{x \to 6}} \sqrt{x + 4} = (\lim_{{x \to 6}}2x - \lim_{{x \to 6}}1) \cdot \lim_{{x \to 6}} \sqrt{x + 4}\].
\[= 11 \cdot \lim_{{x \to 6}} \sqrt{x + 4}\].

easy

Sum Law

Difference Law

Product Law

Difference Law

The Difference Law allows us to separate the limit of a difference into the difference of two limits.

medium

Using the difference law and constant multiple law, how would you express the limit \[\lim_{{x \to 5}} (3x - 2) \sqrt{x + 3}\]?

\[(\lim_{{x \to 5}}3x - \lim_{{x \to 5}}2) \cdot \lim_{{x \to 5}} \sqrt{x + 3}\]

\[(\lim_{{x \to 5}}3x + \lim_{{x \to 5}}2) \cdot \lim_{{x \to 5}} \sqrt{x + 3}\]

\[(\lim_{{x \to 5}}3x - \lim_{{x \to 5}}2) / \lim_{{x \to 5}} \sqrt{x + 3}\]

\[(\lim_{{x \to 5}}3x + \lim_{{x \to 5}}2) / \lim_{{x \to 5}} \sqrt{x + 3}\]

\[(\lim_{{x \to 5}}3x - \lim_{{x \to 5}}2) \cdot \lim_{{x \to 5}} \sqrt{x + 3}\]

Using the difference law and constant multiple law, the limit \[\lim_{{x \to 5}} (3x - 2) \sqrt{x + 3}\] can be expressed as \[(\lim_{{x \to 5}}3x - \lim_{{x \to 5}}2) \cdot \lim_{{x \to 5}} \sqrt{x + 3}\].

difficult

Using the difference law and constant multiple law, how would you express the limit \[\lim_{{x \to a}} (bx - c) \sqrt{x + d}\]?

\[(\lim_{{x \to a}}bx + \lim_{{x \to a}}c) / \lim_{{x \to a}} \sqrt{x + d}\]

\[(\lim_{{x \to a}}bx + \lim_{{x \to a}}c) \cdot \lim_{{x \to a}} \sqrt{x + d}\]

\[(\lim_{{x \to a}}bx - \lim_{{x \to a}}c) / \lim_{{x \to a}} \sqrt{x + d}\]

\[(\lim_{{x \to a}}bx - \lim_{{x \to a}}c) \cdot \lim_{{x \to a}} \sqrt{x + d}\]

\[(\lim_{{x \to a}}bx - \lim_{{x \to a}}c) \cdot \lim_{{x \to a}} \sqrt{x + d}\]

Using the difference law and constant multiple law, the limit \[\lim_{{x \to a}} (bx - c) \sqrt{x + d}\] can be expressed as \[(\lim_{{x \to a}}bx - \lim_{{x \to a}}c) \cdot \lim_{{x \to a}} \sqrt{x + d}\].

Apply the limit of a function rule, which states that \[\lim_{{x \to a}} \sqrt{f(x)} = \sqrt{\lim_{{x \to a}} f(x)}\] if the limit of *f(x)* exists and is non-negative.

In our case, \[\lim_{{x \to 6}} \sqrt{x + 4} = \sqrt{\lim_{{x \to 6}} (x + 4)} = \sqrt{6 + 4} = \sqrt{10}\]

Combine the results:

\[\lim_{{x \to 6}} (2x - 1) \sqrt{x + 4}  = 11 \cdot \sqrt{10}\]

text:
Evaluate \[\lim_{{x \to -2}} (3x^3 - 2x + 7).\]

We know, if \[p(x)\] is a polynomial functions and *a* is a real number. Then,
\[lim_{{x\to a}}p(x)=p(a)\]
We can calculate the limit by substituting *-2* for *x* into the function. Thus,
\[\lim_{{x\to -2}}(3x^3-2x+7)=3(-2)^3-2(-2)+7=-24+4+7=-13\]

text:
Evaluate \[\lim_{{x \to -3}} \frac{{x^2 + 4x + 3}}{{x^2 - 9}}.\]

The function \[f(x) = \frac{x^2+4x+3}{x^2-9}\] is undefined for \[x = -3\]. In fact, if we substitute -3 into the function we get \[\frac{0}{0}\], which is undefined. Factoring and canceling is a good strategy:


\[\lim_{{x \to -3}} \frac{x^2+4x+3}{x^2-9} =\lim_{{x \to -3}} \frac{x^2+x+3x+3}{x^2-9}= \lim_{{x \to -3}} \frac{x(x+1)+3(x+1)}{x^2-9}\]

easy

\[\frac{0}{0}\]

\[\frac{1}{1}\]

\[\frac{-3}{3}\]

\[\frac{3}{-3}\]

\[\frac{0}{0}\]

Substituting -1 into the function\[f(x) = \frac{1-x^2}{x^2-1}\] results in \[\frac{0}{0}\], which is undefined.

What is the factored form of the expression \[\frac{x^2-x-6}{x^2+x-2}\]?

\[\frac{(x+3)}{(x + 2)}\]

\[\frac{(x+3)}{(x - 1)}\]

\[\frac{(x-3)}{(x - 1)}\]

\[\frac{(x-3)}{(x + 1)}\]

\[\frac{(x-3)}{(x - 1)}\]

The expression \[\frac{x^2-x-6}{x^2+x-2}\] factors to \[\frac{(x+2)(x-3)}{(x + 2)(x - 1)}=\frac{(x-3)}{(x - 1)}\].

difficult

What is the factored form of the expression \[\frac{a^2+ab+ac+bc}{a^2-c^2}\]?

\[\frac{(a+b)}{(a - c)}\]

\[\frac{(a-b)}{(a - c)}\]

\[\frac{(a+b)}{(c - a)}\]

\[\frac{(a-b)}{(a - c)}\]

\[\frac{(a+b)}{(a - c)}\]

The expression \[\frac{a^2+ab+ac+bc}{a^2-c^2}\] factors to \[\frac{(a+c)(a+b)}{(a + c)(a - c)}=\frac{(a+b)}{a-c}\].

Now, factorise the denominator and cancel the common factors.

\[\lim_{{x \to -3}} \frac{x(x+1)+3(x+1)}{x^2-9}=\lim_{{x \to -3}} \frac{(x+3)(x+1)}{(x + 3)(x - 3)}=\lim_{{x\to -3}}\frac{x+1}{x - 3}\]

Evaluate \[\lim_{{x \to 5}} \frac{{\sqrt{{x - 1}} - 2}}{{x - 5}}.\]

\[\frac{\sqrt{x-1} - 2}{x-5}\] has the form \[\frac{0}{0}\] at 5. Let’s begin by multiplying by \[\sqrt{x-1} + 2\], the conjugate of \[\sqrt{x-1} - 2\], on the numerator and denominator:


\[\lim_{x \to 5} \frac{\sqrt{x-1} - 2}{x-5} = \lim_{x \to 5} \frac{\sqrt{x-1} - 2}{x-5} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{x-1} + 2}{\sqrt{x-1} + 2}\]

\[-\sqrt{3x-1} + 2\]

\[\sqrt{3x-1} - 2\]

\[\sqrt{3x-1} + 2\]

What is the result of multiplying \[\frac{\sqrt{x-1} - 3}{x-10}\] by its conjugate?

\[\frac{1}{\sqrt{x-1}+3}\]

Multiplying \[\frac{\sqrt{x-1} - 3}{x-10}\] by its conjugate \[\sqrt{x-1} + 3\] results in \[\frac{\sqrt{x-1} - 3}{x-10} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{x-1} + 3}{\sqrt{x-1} + 3}=\frac{(x-1)-9}{(x-10)(\sqrt{x-1}+3)}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{x-1}+3}\]

\[\frac{(a+b)+b^2}{c(\sqrt{a+b}+b)}\]

\[\frac{(a+b)-b^2}{c(\sqrt{a+b}+b)}\]

\[\frac{(a+b)-b^2}{c(\sqrt{a+b}-b)}\]

\[\frac{(a+b)+b^2}{c(\sqrt{a+b}-b)}\]

\[\frac{(a+b)-b^2}{c(\sqrt{a+b}+b)}\]

Multiplying \[\frac{\sqrt{a+b} - b}{c}\] by its conjugate \[\sqrt{a+b} + b\] results in \[\frac{\sqrt{a+b} - b}{c} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{a+b} + b}{\sqrt{a+b} + b}=\frac{(a+b)-b^2}{c(\sqrt{a+b}+b)}\].

We then multiply out the numerator. We don’t multiply out the denominator because we are hoping that the \[(x-5)\] in the denominator cancels out in the end:


\[= \lim_{x \to 5} \frac{(\sqrt{x-1})^2+2\sqrt{x-1}-2\sqrt{x-1}-4}{(x-5)(\sqrt{x-1} + 2)}=\frac{x-5}{(x-5)(\sqrt{x-1} + 2)}.\]
Cancel out the common terms
\[= \lim_{x \to 5} \frac{1}{\sqrt{x-1} + 2}.\]

Evaluate \[\lim_{{x \to 3}} \left( \frac{1}{{x - 3}} - \frac{4}{{x^2 - 2x - 3}} \right).\]

Both \[\frac{1}{x-3}\] and \[\frac{4}{x^2-2x-3}\] fail to have a limit at zero. Since neither of the two functions has a limit at zero, we cannot apply the sum law for limits; we must use a different strategy. In this case, we'll use algebraic simplification to remove indeterminate form.

By looking at the graph we can figure out that the value of function \[f(x)\] as *x* approaches *-1* from left side is *-1*. But we can calculate it without the help of graph by using the definition of \[f(x)\].

\[\lim_{x \to -1^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to -1^-} (-x - 2) =\lim_{x \to -1^-} (-x) - \lim_{x \to -1^-}2 =-(-1)-2 = -1.\]

Evaluate \[\lim_{{x \to 1}} \frac{{x + 2}}{{(x - 1)^2}}.\]

After substituting in \[x = 1,\] we see that this limit has the form \[\frac{3}{0}.\] That is, as *x* approaches 1 , the numerator approaches 3; and the denominator approaches 0.


Since \[x - 1\] is the only part of the denominator that is zero when 1 is substituted, we then separate \[1/(x - 1)\] from the rest of the function:


\[\lim_{{x \to 1}} \frac{x + 2}{(x-1)^2} = \lim_{{x \to 1}} (x + 2) \cdot \frac{1}{(x-1)^2}\]


Now using the Sum law of limits we have,
\[\lim_{{x \to 1}}(x+2)=\lim_{{x \to 1}}x+\lim_{{x \to 1}}2=1+2=3\]

Use the squeeze theorem to evaluate \[\lim_{{x \to 0}} x^2 \sin \frac{1}{x}.\]

Because \[-1 \leq sin\frac{1}{x} \leq 1\] for all *x*, we have \[-x^2 \leq x^2 sin\frac{1}{x} \leq x^2\] , multiplying by \[x^2\] does not change the inequality sign.

So, from the squeeze theorem, we obtain \[\lim_{x \to 0} x^2 sin\frac{1}{x} = 0\].

Evaluate \[\lim_{{\theta \to 0}} \frac{{1 - \cos \theta}}{{\sin \theta}}.\]

In the first step, we multiply by the conjugate so that we can use a trigonometric identity to convert the cosine in the numerator to a sine:


\[\lim_{{\theta \to 0}} \frac{1 - \cos \theta}{sin\theta} = \lim_{{\theta \to 0}} \frac{1 - \cos \theta}{sin\theta} \cdot \frac{1 + \cos \theta}{1 + \cos \theta} \]


\[= \lim_{{\theta \to 0}} \frac{1 - \cos^2 \theta}{sin\theta (1 + \cos \theta)}= \lim_{{\theta \to 0}} \frac{\sin^2 \theta}{sin\theta (1 + \cos \theta)} = \lim_{{\theta \to 0}} \frac{\sin \theta}{1+cos\theta}\]

easy

Which of the following trigonometric identity is correct?

\[\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = \pi\]

\[1 + \sin^2 \theta = \cos^2 \theta\]

\[1 - \cos^2 \theta = \sin^2 \theta\]

\[\sin^2 \theta - \cos^2 \theta = 1\]

\[1 - \cos^2 \theta = \sin^2 \theta\]

According to Pythagorean identity \[\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta = 1\] which can be rewritten as \[1 - \cos^2 \theta = \sin^2 \theta\]

medium

What is the result of multiplying numerator and denominator of the the expression \[\frac{1 + \cos \theta}{sin\theta}\] by the conjugate of \[1+\cos \theta\]?

\[\frac{\sin\theta}{1 + \cos \theta}\]

\[\frac{\sin \theta}{1 - \cos \theta}\]

\[\frac{\cos \theta}{1 + \cos \theta}\]

\[\frac{\cos \theta}{1 - \cos \theta}\]

\[\frac{\sin \theta}{1 - \cos \theta}\]

Multiplying the expression \[\frac{1 + \cos \theta}{sin\theta}\] by the conjugate \[\frac{1 - \cos \theta}{1 - \cos \theta}\] results in \[\frac{1 - \cos^2 \theta}{sin\theta (1 - \cos \theta)}=\frac{\sin^2\theta}{\sin\theta(1-\cos \theta)}=\frac{\sin\theta}{1-\cos\theta}\].

What is the result of simplifying the expression \[\frac{1-\sin \theta}{\cos \theta}\]?

\[\frac{\cos\theta}{1+\sin\theta}\]

\[\frac{\cos\theta}{1-\sin\theta}\]

\[\frac{\sin\theta}{1+\sin\theta}\]

\[\frac{\sin\theta}{1-\sin\theta}\]

\[\frac{\cos\theta}{1+\sin\theta}\]

Multiplying the expression \[\frac{1-\sin \theta}{\cos \theta}\] by the conjugate \[\frac{1 + \sin \theta}{1 + \sin \theta}\] results in \[\frac{1 - \sin^2 \theta}{cos\theta (1 + \sin \theta)}=\frac{\cos^2\theta}{\cos\theta(1+\sin \theta)}=\frac{\cos\theta}{1+\sin\theta}\].

Now evaluate the limit using Quotient rule
\[\lim_{{\theta \to 0}} \frac{\sin \theta}{1+cos\theta}=\frac{\lim_{{\theta \to 0}}sin\theta}{\lim_{{\theta \to 0}}(1+cos\theta)}=\frac{0}{1+1}=0\]


Therefore,
\[\lim_{{\theta \to 0}} \frac{{1 - \cos \theta}}{{\sin \theta}}=0\]

Complete the proof that \[\lim_{{x \to 2}} (3x - 2) = 4\] by filling in the blanks.

\[|\] _______ \[ - \] ____ \[| = \] ______________________________ \[\epsilon.\]

We begin by filling in the blanks where the choices are specified by the \[\epsilon - \delta\] definition of a limit. Thus, we have

Let \[\epsilon > 0\]


Assume \[0 < |x - 2| < \delta\] 

Thus, \[|(3x-2)-4| = |3x - 6| = |3||x - 2| < 3\delta\]


Focusing on the final line of the proof we need to show \[|3||x - 2| < \epsilon\], we see that we should choose \[\delta = \frac{\epsilon}{3}.\]


We now complete the final write-up of the proof:

Choose \[\delta = \frac{\epsilon}{3}.\]


Thus, \[|(3x - 2) - (4)| = |3x - 6| = |3||x - 2| < 3\delta = 3(\frac{\epsilon}{3}) = \epsilon.\]

The \[\epsilon - \delta\] definition of a limit states that for every \[\epsilon > 0\], there exists a \[\delta > 0\] such that if \[0 < |x - a| < \delta\], then \[|f(x) - L| < \epsilon\].

Thus, let \[\epsilon > 0\]. Then we are looking for a \[\delta\] such that \[|x - 9| < \delta \implies |\sqrt{x} - 3| < \epsilon\].

\[|\sqrt{x} - 3| < \epsilon\]

Now, add 3 on both the sides
\[3 - \epsilon < \sqrt{x} < 3 + \epsilon\]
Squaring both sides
\[(3 - \epsilon)^2 < x < (3 + \epsilon)^2\]
Subtracting 9 from both sides
\[(3 - \epsilon)^2 - 9 < x - 9 < (3 + \epsilon)^2 - 9\]

So given \[\epsilon > 0\], we have \[\delta = \min\left\{|(3 - \epsilon)^2 - 9|, |(3 + \epsilon)^2 - 9|\right\}. \]

text:
Complete the proof that \[\lim_{{x \to 1}} x^2 = 1.\]

Let \[\epsilon > 0;\] choose \[\delta = \min\{1, \frac{\epsilon}{3}\};\] assume \[0 < |x - 1| < \delta.\]

Since \[|x - 1| < 1,\] we may conclude that \[-1 < x - 1 < 1.\] Thus, \[1 < x + 1 < 3.\] Hence, \[|x + 1| < 3.\]

Let \[\epsilon > 0\]
Choose \[\delta = \min\{1, \frac{\epsilon}{3}\}\] This choice of \[\delta\] may appear odd at first glance, but it was obtained by taking a look at our ultimate desired inequality: \[\left|x^2 - 1\right| < \epsilon\] This inequality is equivalent to \[\left|x + 1\right| \cdot \left|x - 1\right| < \epsilon\] At this point, the temptation simply to choose \[\delta = \frac{\epsilon}{x + 1}\] is very strong. Unfortunately, our choice of \[\delta\] must depend on \[\epsilon\] only and no other variable. If we can replace \[\left|x + 1\right|\] by a numerical value, our problem can be resolved. This is the place where assuming \[\delta \leq 1\] comes into play. The choice of \[\delta \leq 1\] here is arbitrary. We could have just as easily used any other positive number. In some proofs, greater care in this choice may be necessary. Now, since \[\delta \leq 1\] and \[\left|x - 1\right| < \delta \leq 1\], we are able to show that \[\left|x + 1\right| < 3\]. Consequently, \[\left|x + 1\right| \cdot \left|x - 1\right| < \left|x - 1\right| \cdot 3\]. At this point we realize that we also need \[\delta \leq \frac{\epsilon}{3}\]. Thus, we choose \[\delta = \min\{1, \frac{\epsilon}{3}\}\]

easy

In the proof of a limit, why must our choice of \[\delta\] depend on \[\epsilon\] only and no other variable?

Because \[\epsilon\] represents the desired closeness to the limit

Because \[\epsilon\] represents the actual value of the limit

Because \[\epsilon\] represents the value of the function at the limit

Because \[\epsilon\] represents the difference between the function's value and the limit

Because \[\epsilon\] represents the desired closeness to the limit

In the proof of a limit, our choice of \[\delta\] must depend on \[\epsilon\] only because \[\epsilon\] represents the desired closeness to the limit.

Assume \[0 < \left|x - 1\right| < \delta\]. Thus,
\[\left|x - 1\right| < 1 \text{ and } \left|x - 1\right| < \frac{\epsilon}{3}\]
Since \[\left|x - 1\right| < 1\], we may conclude that \[-1 < x - 1 < 1\]. Thus, by adding 2 to all parts of the inequality, we obtain \[1 < x + 1 < 3\]. Consequently, \[\left|x + 1\right| < 3\]. This gives us
\[\left|x^2 - 1\right| = \left|x - 1\right| \cdot \left|x + 1\right| < \frac{\epsilon}{3} \cdot 3 = \epsilon\]
Therefore,
\[\lim_{x \to 1} x^2 = 1\]

The limit of a function at a point is the value that the function approaches as its argument approaches that point.

The limit of a function at a point is the value that the function approaches as its argument (input) approaches that point. It is a fundamental concept in calculus.

What is the result of multiplying the inequalities \[|a - b| < c\] and \[|a + b| < d\]?

\[|a^2 + b^2| < cd\]

\[|a^2 - b^2| < cd\]

\[|a^2 - 2ab + b^2| < cd\]

\[|a^2 + 2ab + b^2| < cd\]

\[|a^2 - b^2| < cd\]

Multiplying the inequalities \[|a - b| < c\] and \[|a + b| < d\] results in \[|a^2 - b^2| < cd\], because \[a^2 - b^2\] is equivalent to \[(a - b)(a + b)\].
unit: The Precise Definition of a Limit

text:
Find \[\delta\] corresponding to *ε* for a proof that \[\lim_{{x \to 1^-}} \sqrt{1 - x} = 0.\]

Let \[\epsilon > 0\].

Choose \[\delta = \epsilon^2\]. Since we ultimately want \[|\sqrt{1-x} - 0| < \epsilon\], we manipulate this inequality to get \[\sqrt{1-x} < \epsilon\] or, equivalently, \[0 < 1 - x < \epsilon^2\], making \[\delta = \epsilon^2\] a clear choice. 




Assume \[0 < 1 - x < \delta\]. Thus, \[0 < 1 - x < \epsilon^2\]. Hence, \[0 < \sqrt{1-x} < \epsilon\]. Finally, \[|\sqrt{1-x}| < \epsilon\].

Therefore, \[\lim_{x \to 1^-} \sqrt{1-x} = 0\].
